name: For the First: First-Gen Salary Negotiation Workshop
description: In this workshop, Niner Finances will host a session to guide First-Generation Niners on how to negotiate their salary and/or wage upon receiving a job offer. Students will learn how to understand their salary and how it aligns with their lifestyle and responsibilities. Come join us to build your negotiating skills and prepare for your upcoming job offer! name: Jamil Niner Student Pantry: Tuesday Volunteer Shift  |  10:30am – 12:45pm
description:
Volunteer Shifts:
The Jamil Niner Student Pantry assists UNC Charlotte students and faculty/staff who are having challenges accessing food regularly. Through volunteering, you will be working with the pantry leadership team to provide healthy, culturally appropriate, and emergency foods to students, faculty, and staff on campus. Volunteer activities may include, but are not limited to: checking shoppers in and out, assisting with pantry upkeep, stocking and sorting food, garden work, and other various activities to help run the pantry. Please wear closed-toed shoes and comfortable clothing when volunteering at the food pantry. Enter through the front door and proceed to the conference room for volunteer check-in. 
If you are unable to stay for the duration of the volunteer shift, please notify a team member before leaving your shift. 
Questions? Email ninerpantry@charlotte.edu.

description: Want to learn what research looks like in different disciplines? Want to meet researchers at a soon-to-be R1 institution? Want to apply to the OUR Summer Scholars Program? name: Mental Health First Aid
description:
MHFA is an 8-hour training is a national public education program that introduces participants to risk factors and warning signs of mental illnesses and substance use, builds understanding of their impact, and overviews common supports.This course demonstrates how to offer initial help in a mental health crisis and connect persons to the appropriate professional, peer, social, and self-help care. 
 
To register for these sessions, please complete the form found here. Registration is REQUIRED. Walk-ins will not be able to attend.
*** Participants must complete 2 hours of pre-work and attend the full 6 hours of the instructor-led training to earn their certificate.
host: Center for Wellness Promotion, Health and Wellbeing, The Health Education Leadership and Prevention Certificate

name: The Podcaster's Guide to Using AI
description:
AI is all around us! But what does it mean for podcasters who want to make and grow their show in a smart, affordable, and ethical manner? This session will provide a practical, tool-centric guide for harnessing the power of AI platforms -- ranging from Notion to Capsho and beyond -- to streamline and boost your podcast plans. Whether you're interested in learning how to leverage AI to spark new ideas for podcast copy, pitches to media outlets and podcast apps, or visual branding and social media assets, attendees will leave equipped with the knowledge to understand the usefulness of integrating AI tools into their podcast workflow, all while navigating the ethical considerations (and potential pitfalls) of using this emerging technology.
Join Area 49 and Atkins Library for this exciting workshop with Joni Deutsch, Senior Vice President of Podcasting, Marketing and Audience Development at The Podglomerate.
Registation Link: bit.ly/PodAI

name: Hairstory
description: Join us for Hairstory, an empowering event hosted by the Black Student Union in collaboration with Curl Conversations, celebrating the beauty and diversity of Black hair. We’ll explore its rich cultural and historical significance, discuss its impact in professional settings, and break down the harmful "good hair" versus "bad hair" narrative. Attendees will also learn practical hair care tips, discover their hair porosity, and create personalized hair care routines.

name: ASSP Student Section On-Campus Meeting
description:
Hello! We are the American Society of Safety Professionals Student Section. We are affiliated with the local ASSP Tarheel Chapter and our organization is designed for students who are pursuing a career in the safety, health and environmental fields. ASSP seeks to provide additional opportunities for students to learn more about their careers, and interact with safety professionals both on and off campus. These are our monthly (ish) meetings to discuss what's happening in the organization and help plan upcoming events. Some of these meetings may even have guest speakers from the industry!

name: Instant Icons
description:
"Instant Icons" is an interactive event that celebrates Black History Month by encouraging students to document their own history through Polaroid photography. Inspired by the importance of preserving historical moments, this event fosters a sense of belonging and inclusion by allowing students to capture special moments with friends, peers, and mentors.
This initiative aims to highlight the significance of history—both personal and collective—while reinforcing the importance of community, representation, and shared experiences.

name: Mycorrhizae and Me
description: Did you know that plants and fungi stepped hand-and-hand onto land? Even today, about 90% of plants on earth have some sort of fungal association to help them live and grow. In this lecture we’ll talk briefly about the history of fungi on land, some special plant-fungal interactions, and the agricultural and economic benefits of harnessing fungal power in the fields. Come to Mycorrhizae and me to learn more!
host: The Mycology Club of UNC Charlotte

name: Opioid First Aid Training
location: The Waddell Center for Student Health and Wellbeing Room 293
description:
An opioid overdose can happen to anyone, at any time.
 
This FREE one-hour course will provide you with a basic understanding of contributors and risk factors of Opioid Use Disorder, how to recognize the signs/symptoms of a suspected or known opioid overdose, and how to administer/access the opioid reversal medication NARCAN® (naloxone HCL) Nasal Spray.
Designed for all students, faculty, and staff, including lay rescuers and healthcare professionals. 
 
The course is affiliated with The Discover Your Wellness Passport Program and provides a certificate upon completion.
 
*Registration is required for this training. You must register one week prior to the training date. Registration for this event is now CLOSED. This event has reached maximum capacity. Please sign up for the next training offered.
host: Center for Wellness Promotion, The Health Education Leadership and Prevention Certificate

name: Procrastination Workshop Series
location: Visualization Lab, J. Murrey Atkins Library, 2nd floor
description:
Struggling with procrastination? One part of you knows what you should be doing, and another part of you still puts it off until the last minute or doesn't do it at all, so you're left feeling panicked, guilty, or frustrated with yourself. Join us for a workshop addressing common causes of procrastination, including perfectionism and external pressures. We will explore the thoughts, behaviors, and emotions that often prevent us from being as productive and on-task as we would like. We will discuss practical tools to improve time management and accountability, along with ways to reframe your mindset and manage the emotions that come up with procrastination.
 
This is a 3 part workshop happening on 3 consecutive Thursdays. To receive the most benefits, please plan to attend all 3 workshop. Sign up for the other two session:
March 20, 4-5pm
March 27, 4-5pm
host: Counseling and Psychological Services, J. Murrey Atkins Library

name: AIAA Guest Speaker Series  - Rohan Patel, Corvid Technologies
description:
Join the AIAA for our next Guest Speaker Event. During our February event, we will be hosting Rohan Patel of Corvid Technologies.
 
Rohan Patel is a member of the Design and Optimization group at Corvid Technologies, working on aerospace and defense projects. He graduated from Georgia Tech, with a Masters of Science in Aerospace Engineering. His research experience at Georgia Tech was focused on structural topology optimization and multidisciplinary design optimization.
 
Presentation Abstract: 
High-fidelity computational physics plays a critical role in advancing aerospace engineering by enabling the accurate simulation and analysis of complex phenomena across multiple disciplines. This presentation explores the application of these high-fidelity physics to recent advancements in modeling and simulation in three areas: reduced order aerodynamic analysis, aerothermal analysis and structural breakup, and structural optimization.
host: American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Student Branch of the University of North Carolina at Charlotte

name: ACM Weekly Meeting
description:
For Spring 2025, ACM will meet every Wednesday evening in Woodward 154 from 5:30 to 7:00. Students and prospective members should always feel free to drop in late or leave early as needed.
During the first half of our meeting, we usually spend some time socializing and checking in with our peers, since networking is such an important professional skill to develop. For the rest of the time, we'll look at programming/coding problem together and split into pair programming groups to try and come up with solutions collaboratively. We will also set aside some time to discuss current topics and interests in tech and/or spend additional time workshopping resumes or interview skills with our peers.

name: Real Talk Recovery: Recovery Ally Training
location: Student Union: Room 262 8845 Craver Road, Charlotte, NC 28223
description:
The Charlotte Recovery Program (CRP) offers the Real Talk Recovery: Recovery Ally training. As a Recovery Ally, you can play a vital role in normalizing recovery support on and off campus. This training is a part of the H.E.L.P certificate. 
Recovery Ally training equips you to:

Explore the different substances linked to substance misuse and addiction.
Recognize signs, risk factors, and symptoms of someone experiencing substance misuse.
Identify various pathways to recovery from substance misuse and addiction.
Discover resources that students experiencing substance misuse can utilize to receive support.
Acquaint yourself with on-campus and off-campus resources.
Provide tips and ideas to create a substance-free space for yourself and your friends to have fun.
host: Center for Wellness Promotion, Health and Wellbeing, The Health Education Leadership and Prevention Certificate

name: Innovation Barn
description:
The Innovation Barn, the city’s center for circular innovation, is one of the busiestplaces in the city. Its restaurant serves food from its greenhouse and garden, and itscircular stores have a wide variety of upcycled products on offer. It is also a center forexperimentation and education, home to specialized repair facilities and workshopson sustainable design and the potential of waste.
New ideas, ranging from 3D printed plastic building bricks to leather made from fruit peels, are piloted at The Barn, and thenscaled up in many other parts of the city. The Barn has also led to a completely different social dynamic than existed in the 2010s, when the main options for spending time with friends included drinking at a café or bar. People from all corners of the city come to the Barn to learn new skills, but also to socialize while repairing their own clothes or trading their old furniture for something new.
Check out this video on what they do here: Innovation Barn Video
Required LCE Waiver: FILL OUT WAIVER HERE
-Transportation is provided
If you have any questions on this event, feel free to reach out to the Student Director of the Environment and Animals Committee, Zack Lowell via email: zlowell@charlotte.edu

name: Motivation
description:
Many people ponder how they'll motivate others to reach a goal. The tough fact is we can't! We can only encourage others to do so for themselves. Join us to learn how to effectively encourage your team to reach the team's shared and individual goals!
 
This workshop counts towards the Skill Building PILOT credit.

name: Jamil Niner Student Pantry: Tuesday Volunteer Shift  |  12:30pm – 2:45pm
description:
Volunteer Shifts:
The Jamil Niner Student Pantry assists UNC Charlotte students and faculty/staff who are having challenges accessing food regularly. Through volunteering, you will be working with the pantry leadership team to provide healthy, culturally appropriate, and emergency foods to students, faculty, and staff on campus. Volunteer activities may include, but are not limited to: checking shoppers in and out, assisting with pantry upkeep, stocking and sorting food, garden work, and other various activities to help run the pantry. Please wear closed-toed shoes and comfortable clothing when volunteering at the food pantry. Enter through the front door and proceed to the conference room for volunteer check-in. 
If you are unable to stay for the duration of the volunteer shift, please notify a team member before leaving your shift. 
Questions? Email ninerpantry@charlotte.edu.

name: Self-Care With The Lambdas And Poodles
description: “Self-Care with the Lambdas and Poodles” is a collaborative Valentine’s-themed craft night hoisted by Lambda Theta Phi Latin Fraternity, Inc. and Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc., designed to promote self-love, healthy relationships, and community bonding. The event features hands-on activities such as crafting cards for elderly home shelters, creating flowers from innovative materials, and making origami with symbolic shapes. Alongside these interactive stations, a brief educational presentation highlights the importance of self-care and its role in fostering positive relationships and mental well-being. By combining creativity, education, and service, the event fosters a welcoming environment where participants can connect, give back, and leave with valuable insights on personal wellness and meaningful connections.
host: Lambda Theta Phi Latin Fraternity, Inc.

These are hybrid sessions, with a Zoom link available for those who can't join us in the Student Health Center Room 116.

name: Grad, Get to Know Yourself: Signature Character Strengths
description:
Identifying and using our signature character strengths helps us feel authentic, energized, and whole- so what are yours? Our final resiliency workshop takes a deep dive into our greatest strengths, exploring what they are, why they’re important to know, how to cultivate our lesser strengths, and how grad students aware of their strengths can use them to great effect in their academic career. Get to know yourself better, and get better at school!
Workshop participants will need to complete the VIA Character Strengths Survey ahead of time. The assessment should only take about 15 minutes, and the results are free to download. 
This is the final installment of a three-part series. Students are welcome to join one, two, or all three sessions.
Facilitated by: Dr. Aura Young 
Register Here

name: Coffee Bar and Book Swap
description:
Join the Anthropology Graduate Student Association in raising funds for some of our upcoming events!
We will be selling an assortment of drinks and baked goods to raise funds for AGSA. We are also using this as an opportunity to swap a book with your peers! If you have any unwanted or DNF (Do Not Finish) books you want to get off your hands, we encourage you to bring them in! Find your book a new home, possibly find a new book to take home, and have a drink and socialize for a while! We hope to see you there!
RAFFLE: If you spend $10 or more on any café items you'll be entered in a raffle for a chance to win one of two Nespresso Coffee Makers!
Book Swap & Coffee Bar will be held Thursday, Feb. 13th, from 9:00 to 11:00 am in Barnard 244!
P.S. If your Valentine likes to read, you might find a book to give them as a free Valentine's present if you stop by!

name: Grad Student Potluck and International Trivia Night
description:
Where: Atkins 146
When: 4:30 - 6:30pm
Join us for an evening of fun with friends, trying food - and trivia! - from other cultures! You can bring a homemade dish or drink from your culture or buy your favorite snack to share with others. Learn, laugh, and try some great food with awesome people.
Please label your dish with your name and any allergens or dietary restrictions. If your dish has meat, please indicate what kind. (Common allergens include milk, egg, peanut, soy, wheat, tree nut, shellfish, fish.) Pizza and lemonade will also be served!
We look forward to hanging out with you!
Register Here
Facilitator: Sharmeen Hatimbhai, Center for Graduate Life and Learning Global Niner

Then join us for Write Now!Modeled on the popular Shut Up and Write! program, each Write Now! session features two hours of structured writing time for you to focus on making progress on your writing. The Jamil Niner Student Pantry assists UNC Charlotte students and faculty/staff who are having challenges accessing food regularly. Through volunteering, you will be working with the pantry leadership team to provide healthy, culturally appropriate, and emergency foods to students, faculty, and staff on campus. Volunteer activities may include, but are not limited to: checking shoppers in and out, assisting with pantry upkeep, stocking and sorting food, garden work, and other various activities to help run the pantry. Please wear closed-toed shoes and comfortable clothing when volunteering at the food pantry. Enter through the front door and proceed to the conference room for volunteer check-in. 
If you are unable to stay for the duration of the volunteer shift, please notify a team member before leaving your shift.

name: Scenic Heights Rock Climbing
description:
February 15
Join Venture Outdoor Leadership for a day of rock climbing at Rocky Face Mountain Recreation Area! Designed for beginner rock climbers (including those with NO experience), our adventure trip leaders will guide and teach as you enjoy the sunny cliff face of this North Carolina park.
 
Rocky Face Mountain Recreation Area is the traditional home of the Cheraw, Ma'nu (Catawba Indian Nation), Yesan (Tutelo) and Kayauwee (source: native-land.ca).
 
Costs include: Transportation to/from campus; meals; equipment; technical clothing (e.g. rain jackets); instruction. 

Student - $45
Faculty/Staff/Alumni - $50
Community - $60

 
Registration due by Wed, Feb. 12, 12pm.
https://venture.charlotte.edu/adventure-trips/trip-registration

name: Mindfulness Coloring
description:
Take a break from the hustle and immerse yourself in a calming, creative experience at our Mindfulness Coloring Event, hosted by the Mind-Body Wellness Club. This event is designed to help you relax, unwind, and reconnect with your inner peace through the soothing art of coloring.
Coloring isn't just for kids—it’s a powerful tool for practicing mindfulness! Join us as we dive into a relaxing session where you can express yourself through art, reduce stress, and find joy in the present moment. We’ll provide the coloring materials, and you bring your creativity and an open mind.
Come color your stress away and take time to nourish your mind and body. Whether you’re a seasoned artist or just looking for a fun way to relax, this event is for you!


(Sign-up sheet and more information will be sent in out GroupMe for members)

name: Charlotte Rocketry Club 2024-2025 Rocket
description: The Charlotte Rocketry Club creates an environment for students to learn, apply, and engage in aviation, aerospace, and rocketry. The organization has developed a project: to design, build, launch, and safely recover a Level 1 High Power Rocket (HPR) as a team. During the fall semester, students work with the sub-system team of their choosing and begin designing the club rocket. Students will learn how to use Open Rocket to evaluate their designs and then move forward to choosing supplies. During the Spring semester, students then begin the assembly of each individual sub-system until the club as a whole is ready for the final assembly on launch day at the end of the semester. Students will then have the opportunity to travel to Dalzell South Carolina to launch the club rocket in April 2025.

name: Stop the Bleed - 1 Hour Course
location: Waddell Center for Student Health & Wellbeing - Room 293
description:
Stop The Bleed
Life-threatening bleeding injuries can happen anywhere at any time. 
This FREE 1-hour course will teach you to recognize life-threatening bleeding and how to intervene quickly through three techniques: (1) how to apply direct pressure to a wound; (2) how to pack a wound to control bleeding; (3) how to correctly apply a tourniquet.  
Designed for all students, faculty, and staff, including lay rescuers and healthcare professionals. Register for class at StudentHealth.charlotte.edu/classes
The course is affiliated with The Discover your Wellness Passport Program, the H.E.L.P. Certificate Program, and provides a certificate upon completion.
host: Student Health Center, The Health Education Leadership and Prevention Certificate

name: Thursday Night Community Group
description:
Community Group is a great way to make friends that feel like family while also being in an environment that encourages deepening your relationship with God! Community Groups are for people who desire to live life and do life in a Biblical community. These groups meet weekly and rotate between Family Nights and Mission Nights.




Family Nights: a time to gather, worship, encourage one another, and grow through prayer, the Bible, and song.




Mission Nights: a space with people in your community group to either share the gospel with people on campus, eat dinner with people who don’t know Jesus, or do a fun activity to show people who Jesus is as you model a life transformed by the gospel!









 
Join our Thursday Night Community Group GroupMe for weekly details on where we will be meeting! https://web.groupme.com/join_group/102384299/PpQ09XSf

name: Real Talk Recovery: Recovery Ally Training
location: Student Union: Room 262 8845 Craver Road, Charlotte, NC 28223
description:
The Charlotte Recovery Program (CRP) offers the Real Talk Recovery: Recovery Ally training. As a Recovery Ally, you can play a vital role in normalizing recovery support on and off campus. This training is apart of the H.E.L.P certificate. 
Recovery Ally training equips you to:

Explore the different substances linked to substance misuse and addiction.
Recognize signs, risk factors, and symptoms of someone experiencing substance misuse.
Identify various pathways to recovery from substance misuse and addiction.
Discover resources that students experiencing substance misuse can utilize to receive support.
Acquaint yourself with on-campus and off-campus resources.
Provide tips and ideas to create a substance-free space for yourself and your friends to have fun.
host: Center for Wellness Promotion, Health and Wellbeing, The Health Education Leadership and Prevention Certificate

name: Question, Persuade, Refer Suicide Prevention Training for Students
description:
QPR is a 90-minute training intended to foster a community of care by teaching individuals how to recognize the warning signs of suicide, including verbal, behavioral, and situational clues. The training provides guidelines on how to Question a person about suicidal thoughts, Persuade them to get help, and Refer them to campus and/or local resources.
Please use this link to register via zoom at least 48 hours in advance.

name: Time Management
description:
Are you stressed out or don’t have as much time as you want for all of your projects? Do you often postpone things or give up other things because you don't have time?
Learn how to effectively organize your time and tasks so you can accomplish your goals!
Good time management:

allows you to accomplish more in a shorter period of time
leads to more free time, which lets you take advantage of learning opportunities
Lowers your stress
Helps you to focus, which leads to more success in your classes

Register Here
Presenter: Rasheda Sykes (she/her/hers) is the Associate Director of Learning Strategies and Instruction in the University Center for Academic Excellence. name: Your Choices Matter: Academic Publishing Survival Guide
description: Where: Virtual (register for Zoom link)When: 1:00pmThe challenges in academic publishing begin well before the first word hits the page - every grad student knows that. But what many don’t know is that there is a wealth of tools and tips that make the process not only easier, but more fulfilling. Garrison Libby and Jeff McAdams, experts from the Atkins Library, lead this virtual workshop overview of academic publishing - and, more importantly, your agency within it. Learn how to find the right journals for you, get the rundown on open access publishing, and more - there will even be time for a Q&A session at the end. This Survival Guide will show you concrete ways to take control of your research and decide how you put it out into the world. Questions? Contact Garrison Libby (g.libby@charlotte.edu) or Jeff McAdams (jmmcadams@charlotte.edu) in Atkins Library!Register for Here for the Zoom linkPlease note: Our virtual presentations are designed to foster interpersonal interaction, just as a face-to-face meeting would do. For that reason, no digital note-takers, recorders, or other AI-driven programs are permitted in our Zoom workshops. Thank you.
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: 2025 MSA Banquet
description:
A Night to Remember imagine an evening filled with laughter, inspiration, and unforgettable memories!
Students get a significant discount!!!!
PURCHASE TICKETS HERE (EARLY BIRD DISCOUNTS END 2/5):

name: Jamil Niner Student Pantry: Thursday Volunteer Shift  | 10:30am – 12:45pm
description:
Volunteer Shifts:
The Jamil Niner Student Pantry assists UNC Charlotte students and faculty/staff who are having challenges accessing food regularly. Through volunteering, you will be working with the pantry leadership team to provide healthy, culturally appropriate, and emergency foods to students, faculty, and staff on campus. Volunteer activities may include, but are not limited to: checking shoppers in and out, assisting with pantry upkeep, stocking and sorting food, garden work, and other various activities to help run the pantry. Please wear closed-toed shoes and comfortable clothing when volunteering at the food pantry. Enter through the front door and proceed to the conference room for volunteer check-in. 
If you are unable to stay for the duration of the volunteer shift, please notify a team member before leaving your shift. 
Questions? Email ninerpantry@charlotte.edu.

description:

name: Tuesday Night Community Group
description:
Community Group is a great way to make friends that feel like family while also being in an environment that encourages deepening your relationship with God! Community Groups are for people who desire to live life and do life in a Biblical community. These groups meet weekly and rotate between Family Nights and Mission Nights.




Family Nights: a time to gather, worship, encourage one another, and grow through prayer, the Bible, and song.




Mission Nights: a space with people in your community group to either share the gospel with people on campus, eat dinner with people who don’t know Jesus, or do a fun activity to show people who Jesus is as you model a life transformed by the gospel!

name: ACM Weekly Meeting
description:
For Spring 2025, ACM will meet every Wednesday evening in Woodward 154 from 5:30 to 7:00. Students and prospective members should always feel free to drop in late or leave early as needed.
During the first half of our meeting, we usually spend some time socializing and checking in with our peers, since networking is such an important professional skill to develop. For the rest of the time, we'll look at programming/coding problem together and split into pair programming groups to try and come up with solutions collaboratively. We will also set aside some time to discuss current topics and interests in tech and/or spend additional time workshopping resumes or interview skills with our peers.

name: Morrow Mountain Group Hike
description:
Join us for a trip into the near wilderness of North Carolina as we hike and recreate around Morrow Mountain. Cars will be leaving from a meeting place on campus at 9:30am, Saturday February 2nd. Because it takes about an hour to get to the state park from here, we will meet up at the trailhead ~10:40. You are welcome to meet us there, but make sure someone knows that and has your contact for a smooth and easy meetup! Similarly, reach out if you are looking to carpool! No school van so we need to have our numbers right before we meet up and get ready to go.
Pack snacks and water! Sunglasses, hats/head coverings typically good to bring along. Wear layers for a range of temperature, and a windbreak or jacket as necessary per conditions. Possible stops for quick breakfast on the go and/or lunch afterwards depending on cars and schedules.
Don't forget to stay hydrated and get warmed up with some stretches. Both for this trip and also just in general. See you there!
host: GEO Club - Geology and Earth Sciences Organization, The Society of Sigma Gamma Epsilon

name: Spring Break Adventure: Backpacking & Climbing
description:
Spend your spring break with us! We will be exploring the Pisgah National Forest hiking a few miles each day, carrying what we need in our backpacks, and setting up our campsite in a new location each afternoon/ evening. We'll set up camp and then cook dinner together. We will share sleeping space in tents (2 to 4 people per tent).  Weather permitting, we will take a break from hiking for a day of rock climbing. 
No experience is necessary for this trip. First time campers, hikers, and rock climbers are welcome!
Costs include: Transportation to/from campus; meals; equipment; technical clothing (e.g. rain jackets); instruction.

name: Write Now!
description:
Register Here for Zoom Link
Are you working on a piece of writing? Could you benefit from some extra accountability and motivation to make progress? Then join us for Write Now!Modeled on the popular Shut Up and Write! program, each Write Now! session features two hours of structured writing time for you to focus on making progress on your writing. Participating in structured writing times benefits graduate and postdoctoral writers by allowing them to strengthen writing habits, make meaningful progress on writing projects, and improve attitudes about writing (Cayley et al., forthcoming; Tremblay-Wragg et al., 2021).
Whether you're writing an article, working on a dissertation chapter, preparing to defend your thesis, or just trying to get some work done, Write Now! is right for you!
Facilitator: Caitlin BrabbleRose

name: Student-Centered Assessment Leaders
description:
To advance the culture of evidence and embed student-centered assessment into our assessment practices, Student Affairs Research and Assessment is offering a new professional development opportunity, Student-Centered Assessment Leaders.  This program takes place over two days during spring break and consists of six workshops: (1) Orientation and Introduction to Student-Centered Assessment, (2) Including Students in the Assessment Process, (3) Using Multiple Sources of Evidence, (4) Disaggregating & Interpreting Data 101, (5) Increasing Transparency in Assessment Results and Actions Taken, (6) Telling your Story, and (7) Putting it all together: Student-Centered Assessment Action Plan. Once participants have finished this series, they will have the skills necessary to not only incorporate these practices in their own assessment but also train others in this important work. 
This is a cohort-based program, all workshops will be in-person, and attendance is required at every workshop. To register for this program, please complete this registration form by February 14 at 11:59 pm. Below are the workshop dates and times, locations will be provided at a later date.

name: Goal Setting
description:

description: Join RA Mya, RA Kendel, RA Trenity, and RA Chelsea in the Valentine’s Day Extravaganza! There’s going to be music, food, super fun events and even finding your match!

description: A joyous, emotional, heartbreaking celebration of the life and music of Whitney Houston, one of the greatest female R&B pop vocalists of all time, tracking her journey from obscurity to musical super stardom.

name: Lovers Lane Ball
description: Come enjoy a night of dance and music. Grab a mocktail, write a letter of appreciation, and take some photos at our DIY photo booth.       We have a DIY photobooth to come and enjoy yourselves with friends. This workshop is first come, first serve for seating.

host: Programs in Leadership and Organizational Training

name: Financial Services Career Fair
description: The Financial Services Career Fair connects students and alumni with employers in the financial services industry who may be recruiting in the areas of banking, data analytics, employee benefits, financial advising, risk management insurance, actuarial, sales, technology computer science.The Financial Services Career Fair gives you the opportunity to network directly with leading financial services companies offering career and internship positions. Students and alumni from all majors in the Belk College of Business are encouraged to attend; the event is free. Professional Attire is required.

name: Jamil Niner Student Pantry: Thursday Volunteer Shift  |  2:30pm – 5:15pm
description:
Volunteer Shifts:
The Jamil Niner Student Pantry assists UNC Charlotte students and faculty/staff who are having challenges accessing food regularly. Through volunteering, you will be working with the pantry leadership team to provide healthy, culturally appropriate, and emergency foods to students, faculty, and staff on campus. Volunteer activities may include, but are not limited to: checking shoppers in and out, assisting with pantry upkeep, stocking and sorting food, garden work, and other various activities to help run the pantry. Please wear closed-toed shoes and comfortable clothing when volunteering at the food pantry. Enter through the front door and proceed to the conference room for volunteer check-in. 
If you are unable to stay for the duration of the volunteer shift, please notify a team member before leaving your shift. 
Questions? Email ninerpantry@charlotte.edu.

name: 3D Modeling Workshop
description:
Learn how to construct your first design for 3D printing using TinkerCAD. This workshop is open to all levels of makers, no 3D modeling experience necessary. Please bring your own laptop.
Registration required and open to current UNC Charlotte students, staff, and faculty.

name: ETD Copyright in 30 Minutes
description:
Do you want to publish a book or scholarly article? Are you thinking of working with a publisher to bring your scholarly work to a wider audience?   If so, join us for this workshop, tailored to academic authors. We’ll cover the basics of copyright law, negotiation, publication contract terms, and UNC Charlotte’s policies…before you agree to a deal with a publisher.
This workshop is facilitated by Arnetta Girardeau, who also created a video on the topic. You can view it here; while not required before attending the workshop, it will help you shape your questions when you are there.
Register Here for Zoom link
Please note: Our virtual presentations are designed to foster interpersonal interaction, just as a face-to-face meeting would do. For that reason, no digital note-takers, recorders, or other AI-driven programs are permitted in our Zoom workshops. Thank you.
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: Pool and Billiards Club First/Interest Meeting
description:
Looking to shoot some pool? Stop by our first meeting to learn more about the Pool and Billiards Club – all skill levels welcome!
 
Please note: Our first meeting date is being rescheduled while we finalize the arrangements. Stay tuned for updates as we hope to start this month!

name: Intersectional Justice Alliance Weekly Meeting
description: Weekly meetings to discuss and plan ways to educate, understand, and act on our issues. Our current issue is immigration. We want to understand how UNCC and Charlotte feel about immigration and the problems and conflicts surrounding immigration. We then want to take this information and educate the community and act to solve issues.
host: Intersectional Justice Alliance at UNC Charlotte

name: Networking Across Cultures
description:
Time: 4:00 - 5:00pm
Location: Dubois Center Room 1105
 
Most people feel a little intimidated about networking, and this is especially true when you are new to a culture. Are you familiar with the saying, "it's not what you know, it's who you know?"
 
In the US, connections with people carry a lot of weight when looking for a job. This is why networking is a fundamental skill for launching and furthering your career. However, when we hear the word "networking," we often think of "doing lunch," selling ourselves, and handing out business cards. If we changed the word to “connecting,” we might feel better about it. Your job search begins with the people you know! Never underestimate their knowledge and influence. Most people are enthusiastic about connecting and see it as mutually beneficial.
 
Register Here
 
Facilitator: Robin Boswell
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: 3D Printer Training
description:
Learn how to set your own print on the 3D printers. After completing this training, you will be able to reserve and use the 3D printers in the Area 49 Makerspace on your own.
Registration required and open to current UNC Charlotte students, staff, and faculty.

name: Time Management
description:
Come learn time management skills with LEAD team. Engage in a fun workshop that will help you manage your time better.
This will count for a skill-building credit for PILOT.
host: Programs in Leadership and Organizational Training

name: Adjusting to American Culture: Storytelling + Show and Tell
description:
Where: Atkins 146
 
When: 3:00 - 4:00pm
 
The Adjusting to American Culture events are designed to support international students who have recently moved to the United States and are experiencing cultural challenges. Each event provides students from all over the world a chance to connect, learn, and share in a casual, relaxed, and social environment.
 
Share your culture with your fellow international students! Bring items, photos, or other souvenirs from home to showcase, and enjoy the stories and souvenirs of others. This is an opportunity to deepen your understanding of other places, as well the bond to your own home. We hope to see you there! Coffee and snacks will be served!
 
Register Here
 
Facilitator: Sharmeen Hatimbhai, Center for Graduate Life and Learning Global Niner
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: Exploring the Italian Renaissance
description: Come explore the Italian Renaissance with the Italian Club! Play a Trivia-Based Kahoot for an Authentic Italian Gift Basket, including items such as Torrone, Ferrera Cookies, and Pasta. There will be as much Espresso as you can enjoy, so ring in Carnevale with us as we explore the history and culture behind it!

name: Scrimmage
description: The Gold Rush Scrimmage is one of our last benchmarks when preparing for the IEEE hardware competition! During this event, we test our robot on the field, and troubleshoot how far we have to go in the final stretch from competition. We have fun, troubleshoot, brainstorm, and have a good time! Whether you have been working on the bot for the last few months or not, stop by to learn what we've been up to!

name: Problem Solving
description:
Come join the LEAD team in helping explore the topic of problem-solving. Learn new and innovative ways to reframe problems and help be more efficient in problem-solving.
 
This will count for a Critical Thinking Credit for PILOT.
